positive.review: If you think you're the ultimate survivor and/or can/could survive in a zombie apocalypse, this game is the reality check.

This is another year that I've added this wonderful game to the "Labor of Love Award" category. It's already become a tradition, but this year I wanted to write a review.
I can't remember how many years ago I started playing this game, a long time ago, back when the game had a 2D version. But back then, I was scared to play solo :D
I'm crazy about the zombie apocalypse genre, and I'm always trying out new projects, both story-driven and sandbox, but Zomboid will always be at the top of my list because it gives me that same feeling of loneliness and hopelessness, but at the same time, the desire to fight and explore.
It's never boring to come back to it, because every time I played, I experienced new events and a new story, I still remember many of my characters :3
And now there will also be updated crafting, cooler construction, and livestock farming. I really like itüê•üíï
Playing with friends is also a really fun experience. I still remember how we had an event with helicopters. In the process, we accidentally burned down our house, and I tried to save my friend and killed her in a car accident. It was both funny and sad, I still remember the fine times we had.
The game is great, you should definitely try it despite the graphics.
Beautiful graphics are found in many modern games, but freedom, cool gameplay mechanics, and such an atmosphere are rare.

I left the garage door open AND the door leading into the house.
That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs the whole story.
A great zombie game that let's you live a life and try to survive a zombie outbreak. Its a real world sim with a zombie element.

Project Zomboid is such a banger of a game. Legit one of the best sandbox games I‚Äôve ever played, and probably my favourite survival game overall. The soundtrack is great, the atmosphereis great, and the jumpscares actually get you sometimes even though it's a low poly game, which i never thought could be scary.

I haven‚Äôt tried multiplayer yet so I can‚Äôt say much about that part. The devs did make some pretty questionable changes in Build 42 and the game definitely feels harder for no real reason, but I‚Äôm hoping they‚Äôll balance things out before the final release.

When I first started, I kept dying in like the first couple of days. The learning curve is steep and the leveling system can be grindy, but you can adjust the settings to make things more manageable.

Also, the modding community is fucking amazing. Love those bastards as well.

Overall, it‚Äôs easily one of my favourite games I‚Äôve played so far.

Anyways this is a no-brainer for anyone interested in Survival or apocalyptic games.

It's a very good game, definitely worth buying, but there are a few catches.

It is way beyond a barebones game, you have many hours of content, thats not really the problem. The problem is, after all those hours, you'll be left thinking "why did I do all this?"
Theres literally no endgame. You will spend hours raising your skills, building your base, getting supplies, etc, all for there to be no threats at all once you cleared your area.
The only real answer to that as of now is multiplayer, but thats on the main version, Build 41, which is 4 years old. Development is extremely slow, to the point that, when things actually come, any excitement has died out. Devs keep hiring modders but nothing gets done. Players tell the dev team what they want and they do something else while adding more new systems and frameworks, instead of fixing and expanding on current ones first. No big lategame objectives. No wandering hordes. No human enemies (or friends). No real rewards or incentives for growing skills past a certain point.

Which is a shame because this could easily become THE definitive survival game. When you start it, it really sucks you into the world. Its the most immersive game I've played, which says alot considering the graphics and perspective. It allows you to do so many things you wouldnt even have thought of.
From finding the keys to a vehicle or learning to hotwire it, to learning how to make doors and windows, to finding random furniture for your house, collecting a bunch of unique items, play dressup, make a garden, and much more. 

But it's ultimately not about what the game offers, it's about what it doesn't. If you're wondering what that is, just check the Workshop or any discussion forum for this game, because the list goes on and on.

So while, yes, i do recommend this game, i do so with a pinch of salt, because it could be so much better than it is, and it shows no signs of improving. I do hope the devs prove me wrong and pull like 3 updates next year, but by the way things are going, TES6 is releasing before the next build.

A lot of people have said this is their perfect zombie game, and I have to agree. From the moment you load the tutorial, the isometric perspective makes it a novel experience. Speaking for Build 41 (I hear B42 is a bit worse in this aspect, for now), the menus are not intuitive at a first glance, but become second nature very fast, especially if you're a regular PC user. The soundtrack is excellent; the songs still sound new and varied to me, and perfectly fit whatever I'm doing in game. The combat is simple, but tense, due to how easy it is to let your guard down. The fact you can't see what's behind you is a great choice, as is not knowing what is behind the next door or corner. Hearing a gurgle and not knowing if it came from upstairs, the window outside or the door on your right never gets old. As for why this could be the best zombie game ever, it's simple: If you don't like the default settings, want to make it easier or harder, or want your perfect apocalypse, it's all there. And if you want something more, there's a crazy workshop available. For the price, it's a no-brainer. Best part is Build 41 already feels like a fully developed game, and yet there's more to come.

Look, I died because I thought I could cook salmon safely. I didn‚Äôt read the manual‚Äîturns out electrical fires are a thing when your oven goes rogue. One minute I‚Äôm living my best post-apocalyptic chef life, the next? I‚Äôm a crispy shadow on the wall, 10/10 would die to dinner again.

I‚Äôve spent 150+ hours in this game and still haven‚Äôt survived winter. I‚Äôve been bitten, starved, depressed, chased by one zombie that somehow turned into 50, and once got stuck in a bathroom with a raccoon I thought was dead. Spoiler: it wasn‚Äôt. The game doesn‚Äôt just kill you‚Äîit embarrasses you on the way out.

But that‚Äôs why I love it. Project Zomboid isn‚Äôt about winning. It‚Äôs about the stories you tell while failing spectacularly. Want to farm corn in Kentucky while wearing a traffic cone as a hat? Go ahead. There is a mod for that, Try to hotwire a cop car only to immediately crash into a gas station and summon every zombie in six counties? Been there. The modding community keeps it fresh, the updates keep improving it, and the sheer nerdiness of its survival systems is beautiful.

It‚Äôs janky? Sure. The UI looks like it was designed in 2003? Absolutely. But that‚Äôs part of the charm. This game doesn‚Äôt hold your hand‚Äîit kicks you into the apocalypse and says, ‚ÄúGood luck, dumbass.‚Äù

Highly recommend. Just‚Ä¶ maybe learn about fire safety first.

Project Zomboid is one of the most immersive (survival) games i have ever played. The deep mechanics and vast amount of content can keep you playing forever. It never gets old. It's great with friends and even better with mods!

The graphics and the sound design are gritty, atmospheric, and perfectly reflect the 1990s inspiration. Gameplay-wise, it is brutally unforgiving, and it‚Äôll take you a long time to master its systems, and there are a lot of them. From managing hunger and injuries to navigating moods, skills, and the ever-present undead threat, every mechanic matters.
The exploration and survival are no different, although some people find scavenging for supplies harder than fighting zombies, and vice versa. The game offers an enormous variety of situations to overcome, with dynamic events, weather, and AI behaviors that constantly force you to adapt, keeping you on edge throughout your run. The world itself also delivers plenty of surprises, from varied building layouts to different zombie population patterns.
Overall, it‚Äôs hard but fair, and it keeps you on your toes, wether you enjoy it will depend entirely on how you handle having your patience tested and the constant risk of losing everything to a single mistake. 
But for a guy like me, I‚Äôd absolutely recommend it.

[h2]NO ONE WILL MOURN YOU[/h2]
Great zombie survival game, honestly one of it's kind. I don't think you can find one that matches the depth and open survival like this one. This game has a very large learning curve, you will die. It's not even me just saying you will die from learning (which will be true, when you are new), but your game ends when you basically die. The whole premise is you are living out your life until you eventually die, as the game introduces you to a text that says [spoiler]"This is how you died."[/spoiler]

 [h2]THESE ARE THE END TIMES[/h2]
Anyways great game, interesting mechanics and depth you can achieve in it. The modding community is large, but updates have been slow. We are still waiting for the stable launch of B42, which will include animals and the largest map expansion to Knox Country. B43, we are looking at possibly npcs being added, so that will be exciting too. 

[h2]EVERYTHING WILL HAVE BEEN FOR NOTHING[/h2]
It's a sandbox survival and it is punishing. The game has an interesting story behind it too, I'd watch lore videos if you are interested, but there is a whole timeline, and meta events that happen. It gets fun when you actually learn the game, just don't give up on it. Be smart when you play, and you'll survive long, although I doubt anyone can legitimately survive forever. I wish you luck if you choose to take on this adventure.

The game opens with the beautiful line: "This is HOW you died."

I love this game. However there are some serious issues with its development. The first and biggest is the way and the time-frame in which they handle updates. Zomboid only does major updates so no minor ones at all(other bug fixes or when its in unstable), and each time its a minimum of 3 years before it comes out. This on its own would be bad but then each time they add a major update the game goes into unstable branch for another 3 years. During this time the new update is available with no multiplayer and mp is disabled on every new update... for at least 3 years... Yes you can still play multiplayer on the old version but of course you wont have any new features to try out. This is such a bad way of handling things. The slow update schedule would feel far better if there was at least MP but instead you sit waiting years for it to come out. It splits the community, it leaves modders split between making mods for the new build (which you can only enjoy solo for 3 years) and making/maintaining mods for the old version because all MP servers are still using the old build and thus the old mods, but this also means less people are making mods for the old version so the old version doesn't really even get new mods either so you are stuck with no new content even in the form of new mods for years. 

Handling updates this way is nonsensical and if you dare to try mention or discuss the lengthy wait between updates on the community page you get bombarded by a horde of white knights and power tripped community moderators who hand out community bans/warnings for using the word "clown" to describe someone but only if you are being critical of the game, if you are white knighting it you can say it all you want and white knights who will defend anything even the removing of multiplayer for the release of a major update. Imagine if every time call of duty added a new season or did a major update they disabled multiplayer for 3 years... the game would be dead. The devs have complained at the community before for speaking up about some of these issues saying in as many words "it makes it hard for them to work on the game when people are speaking negatively about it". Essentially saying stop complaining or we will stop developing the game. Its a shame because the game itself is incredible, there really is nothing like it. And again the incredibly long update release schedule would probably feel less bad if multiplayer was available straight away but instead you will wait as long for that as you did for the update in the first place. At 6 years per update wait 30 years until the game is fully realised and then you'll be fine or if you don't care about new content and updates being added outside of mods which even they will become fewer and fewer as a new update goes into unstable branch then go for it. In my opinion if they cant manage to release a major update without breaking multiplayer then just do smaller more regular updates where multiplayer can continue to work because making it work with 1 new feature will be a lot quicker than doing it for the 100 new things in a major update. 

I didn't want to put this in a negative review but indie stone need to sort out their community moderators who are tripping out of their minds on the minuscule amount of power they have been given and are censoring criticism and discontent people are having over the issues i laid out among others. I would not have left this review if not for the censorship of zomboids community page and the side taking of its moderators who hand out community warnings to you if you are critical but if you are defending it you can say the same thing and be fine.

I bought this back in 2017, after having this on wishlist for a while and following drama with the development. Played it for an hour, hated it, thought it was in Early Access so they would improve it.

[h3]EDIT: I tried to play it again, this time in builder difficulty, but I just can't.[/h3]

The world is way too uninteresting and all you do is.. eat, drink, wash, sleep and kill. Then again, I find such pointless survival "slider-watchers" boring in any other game as well these days, so chances of this game impressing me with this stale survival style are none.

[h3]EDIT 2: Tried again.[/h3]

Sneak around > kill a zombie or two >  get inside and loot > cook > eat > drink > wash > sleep > read something (and by that, I mean watch sliders move). That's the whole game in 3.9 hrs. I know there is base building and all that jazz as well, but I don't really care that much about grown virtual plants and trees unless it's a game like Stardew Valley (mostly cause this game already feels like a chore without that element).

I'm thinking, I'll try custom sandbox difficulty next and lower the zombie to the lowest possible, without removing them. Because ironically, Zombies are the biggest drawback of the game called "Project Zomboid", all thanks to the dog-shit combat (again, devs had Diablo and Grim Dawn to copy combat from, yet they went with.. this).

If there are only a few Zombies, I can explore more and not get bored trying to just eat and drink while sitting in same spot, watching sliders move for hours.

I know I kinda said I would try sandbox, but I just installed Void Bas_tards (which I bought ages ago) and started playing it. 3 hrs in, I realized that game was ten times more fun than even 30 mins inside Zomboid, so I uninstalled Zomboid and binned it into a category where I just dump games I'll never touch. For a game that focuses on ''realism'' there are a lot of things that make 0 sense, like weapon durability; A tire iron made out of heat treated steel wouldn't break after killing 7 zombies, an axe wouldn't break after cutting down 4 trees... This is just blatant disrespect of the player's time disguised as ''difficulty''. Yes there is a sandbox mode but it doesn't have a slider for weapon durability which is really bad design. Also the traits system is really bad, if you pick a profession you need to pick like 5 negative traits to offset the negative points it gives you. All that for an almost useless bonus. Picked carpenter? Still can't build stairs. Picked mechanic? Still can't change engine parts. Prepare for the most tedious grind of your life to level up skills (1.5 exp per action, 90 000 exp required to level up) that you can all lose in a single moment when a zombie lands an instantaneous lucky bite on you because of one of the game's numerous frame freezes or combat bugs, leading to your death and loss of all your skill points. Completely ridiculous. According to this game i'm a real life super hero because I have to give myself 60 free trait points in sandbox settings to make a character that is true to my real life build. I'm just that much of a hardcore badass I guess. OR maybe the devs are a bunch of pencil neck dweebs that have never worked a manual labor job a single day in their lives and have no clue of how the real world works since they think dragging 2-3 corpses or cutting down 2-3 trees will exhaust and cripple you to a complete stop for 3 hours. 

Oh and the community is absolutely rancid and has a weirdly disproportionate quantity of basement dwelling tr00ns and furries forming a cult around it. They will harass you and permanently kick you out of the discord if you politely criticize the game in any shape or form and all of that on the first offense. This is pretty much a multiplayer death sentence since there are no ways in game to find other players to play with, no server list, no searching for games etc. From what I have heard and seen the developpers seem just as cringe and unprofessional when engaging with criticism. One of the devs would get on Twitter drunk and tell people to kts. (instead of actually working on the game lol)  

TL;DR: Unacceptable development speed (early Access for 12+ years, slow mediocre updates), bad UI, bad combat, bad skill system, buggy, misguided sense of realism, tedious gameplay loop (inventory management simulator) cringe community and cringe devs.

I tried playing this coop with a friend but after many tries there were just too many game breaking bugs (at least in that game mode) - such as the game going out of sync and resulting in both of us dying. Figuring out the multiplayer settings is also challenging - the flow is a little awkward, and understanding what settings would be appropriate for first-time players is unclear (the default settings seem too difficult when you're still learning the game mechanics). There are also some other lesser irritations such as the display settings not setting resolution correctly, not honoring v-sync settings, font scale up not working properly, and a couple crashes. Reading other reviews, there may well be a fantastic game beyond all of these issues, but after a few hours of trying to get it up & running, we moved on to the next game on our list. So in its current state I couldn't recommend this game to players coming at it for the first time.
